intro: Ballota nigra subsp. kurdica, commonly known as Kurdish blackball, is a perennial herb native to the mountainous regions of the Eastern Mediterranean and parts of the Middle East. It belongs to the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its dark purple to black seed pods. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with hairy stems and trifoliate leaves. Its flowers are small, pink to purple, and clustered in racemes, blooming in late spring to early summer. The subspecies is notable for its hardy nature and ability to thrive in rocky and arid environments.
